docs.lead_paragraph: In the St. Thomas housing project, with its rows of boarded-up red brick buildings, the ghosts speak more eloquently than the living about the despair at the bottom of urban America. There's the spindly crape myrtle tree and a modest plaque marking the spot where 5-year-old Coco Vessel died in a crossfire of bullets on Nov. 19, 1989. There's a weed-choked patch outside the apartment where Elnora Barnes for many years tended her begonias and roses, green peppers, eggplant and okra before gunfire drove her away.

headline.main: As Urban Blight Worsens, Victims Find Their Isolation Is Deepening

docs.snippet: In the St. Thomas housing project, with its rows of boarded-up red brick buildings, the ghosts speak more eloquently than the living about the despair at the bottom of urban America.   There's the spindly crape myrtle tree and a modest plaque marking...

byline.original: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Nearly three decades after the Great Society, and after eight years of record economic growth, urban poverty remains an entrenched force in American life and an increasingly destructive one. Homelessness, underclass, crack, AIDS -- the past decade has challenged dictionaries to keep pace as it redefined city suffering. Some wonder whether such words spell a permanent change in the definition of America itself.

headline.main: Suffering in the Cities Persists As U.S. Fights Other Battles

byline.original: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Large numbers of nursing home residents are tethered to their beds or wheelchairs or given powerful tranquilizing drugs without documentation that they are needed, two new studies show. Twelve nursing homes in southern Connecticut were studied by researchers at Yale University. At the start of the study, 59 percent of the residents were physically restrained. Within the next year, 31 percent of the remaining residents were restrained at some point.

headline.main: Nursing Homes Are Criticized on How They Tie and Drug Some Patients
